My safe's contain little to no cash. Important documents, precious metals, and weapons are pretty much all I have room for. Besides, ITSTHTF paper currency and most coinage minted after 1964 is going to be worthless anyway, aside from bullion/commemorative coins with high silver or gold content. I've got a couple TINY gold pieces, quarter eagles I think they are. TINY things that make a dime seem imposing beside them, and no ridges on the edges (a bad design idea). They're in VERY good shape, a gift from my dad last time he was down. I think they have a $2.50 or $5 face value. Well, that was the American dollar when it was something other than a fiat currency, and we didn't have wild inflation, market speculation, and "bubbles" which could destroy the economy when they collapsed when things had to be paid for with hard specie. So, the one additional step after converting everything to cash . . . convert the cash to something more universally fungible and more compact. American dollars aren't going to be worth carrying around in a suitcase in another 20 years.

CNN Panel: Dorner's Alleged Murder Spree 'Exciting, Like 'Denzel Washington Movie' Panelists MC Lyte, Jack Moore, Editor of BuzzFeed Sports, Lauren Ashburn, Editor-in-chief at The Daily Download, and Mark Lamont Hill joined Brooke Baldwin on CNN today to talk about the social media support for alleged quadruple killer Christopher Dorner. Ashburn was the only one on the panel who had a problem with the alleged cop killer being celebrated saying that he crossed a line when he began killing people to get his revenge for his alleged grievences. The rest of the panel concluded that Dorner "had a point" and that the unfolding story was theatric. Hill said that the saga was "exciting," "like 'Django Unchained' in real life," and Dorner was similar to a "super hero." Moore said that it was like watching a "Denzel Washington movie" and that the social media support was just Internet "weirdness." Lyte concluded that because "children" were being killed by police brutality this event brought about a conversation that should occur. Baldwin agreed and said, "I'm glad we had this conversation".
Please, show exactly what's larger than needed. Lean Penetta on military cuts: "one of the greatest security risks we are now facing."

You don't want to talk about cuts in any social programs which are going completely out of control. You don't want sequestration because it is going to touch everything you don't want to cut .Military cuts are your least concern. Yes, Penetta was referring to sequestration affect on military. But didn't you mean we shall cut it at least in half?

US military is not a social program in the first place. But you put it in this category. It is mercenary according to you at the same time. This is why I gave you parallel with Medicare. If big pharma rips benefits by manufacturing drugs for sick elderly, what's wrong with private business making profit by selling their technology to Department of Defense?
